voice_to_text: What funny family story do you now realise was actually kind of messed up? My Uncle Rusty was always the fun uncle who'd entertain all the kids. He was this larger than life guy who could do magic tricks and always had candy in his pockets. All the neighborhood kids loved him. He wasn't married and didn't have kids of his own, so he'd basically adopt all of us for the day. One particular barbecue stands out because of what happened with my little cousin Aria. She was maybe four at the time and super shy around everyone except me. She followed me everywhere that day, which was kind of annoying because I was trying to hang out with the older kids. So Uncle Rusty announces he's gonna do this new magic trick and all the kids gather around. I remember being super excited because his tricks were always amazing. He asks for a volunteer and picks Arya. Surprised me because she was so shy, but she went up all excited. The trick was supposed to be him making a quarter disappear and then pulling it out of her ear. Pretty standard stuff. But what happened next is the funny story my family cannot stop telling. When Uncle Rusty reached toward Aria's ear, she freaked out, like, full on screaming, crying, trying to run away. My aunt had to come grab her while everyone was laughing because they thought she was just being dramatic. Uncle Rusty played it up, acting All offended, which made all the adults laugh even harder. The next part is what my family thinks is hilarious. Uncle Rusty decided to get revenge on Arya for ruining his trick. Every time she'd calm down, he'd slowly approach her with a quarter, and she'd start screaming again. This went on all day. By the end of the barbecue, he just had to pull a quarter from his pocket and hold it up, and she burst into tears. My parents, aunts, uncles, they were literally crying from laughing so hard. They kept saying how funny it was that she was so scared of something so harmless. This became Uncle Rusty's bit with Aria. At every family gathering after that, he'd pull out a quarter and wave it at her, and everyone would crack up when she'd get upset. I remember one Thanksgiving when I was about 12, Aria was hiding under the dining room table before dinner. I crawled under there to see what was up, and she whispered that she was hiding from Uncle Rusty because she knew he'd do the quarter thing again. She was literally shaking, and I remember thinking it was kind of weird how scared she still was. I told her she was being a baby, which makes me feel terrible now. At Christmas that same year, Uncle Rusty took it to another level. He wrapped a small box for Aria, and when she opened it, there were, like, 50 quarters inside. She dropped The box! And ran crying from the room while all the adults howled with laughter. My mom still brings this up as the funniest Christmas moment ever. When Arya turned 10, her parents threw her this big birthday party with a magician. As soon as the magician started pulling coins out for tricks, Aria had a complete meltdown. Everyone thought it was so funny that she was still doing this bit. The magician was confused, but Uncle Rusty filled him in, and even he started incorporating quarters into all his tricks specifically to scare Aria. A grown adult professional deliberately terrifying a child on her birthday. And everyone thought it was comedy gold. I was too young to really process it then, but looking back now, I'm like, we were literally traumatizing this little girl for years and treating it like a hilarious joke, and the adults were encouraging it. The story got darker when I was home last month helping my mom clean out some old photo albums. We found pictures from those barbecues, and there was one of Aria crying while Uncle Rusty held a quarter near her. My mom was like, Omg, remember how funny that was? And I just couldn't laugh. I asked mom if she ever wondered why Aria was so terrified that first time, and mom just shrugged and said, kids are weird. But I couldn't stop thinking about it, so I called Aria. We're not super close, but we follow each other on Social media. I asked her if she remembered the quarter trick and if she knew why she was so scared. There was this long pause on the phone. Then she told me something that made my stomach

Sarah McKinley, a young mother, noticed a group of suspicious men loitering around her house, one of whom was holding a crowbar. She recognized that one of them was the person who had been following her recently. Her husband passed away on Christmas Day, leaving only her and her three month old child at home, which made Sarah more and more anxious. He called 9 1 1 for help. But just as she was calling the dispatcher, those men began to try to force their way through the front door. Worried about her and the child's life safety, Sarah picked up her weapon and loaded it. She kept asking the 9 1 1 operator if she was allowed to protect herself with a weapon. The dispatcher comforted her calmly that she had the right to do everything possible to protect her child. When one of the intruders finally broke in, Sarah immediately pulled the trigger and k I l l him. The others were panicked and fled the scene after seeing their companions fall. Sarah remained highly vigilant, holding the child in one hand and a weapon in the other until the police arrived. The authorities later confirmed that Sarah's actions were in line with her legal rights and she would not face any charges. Do you think this Is a legitimate act of self defense. voice_to_text: A man who raped and killed a three year old girl has died only one month into his 20 year prison sentence. Thirty four year old Robert Fisher was sentenced to 20 years to life behind bars for the rape and murder of three year old Josephina Cunningham. Fisher had forced the girl to consume her mother's medication. He then attacked her and tried to cover up what he had done. Fisher had befriended the child's mother and the child was left in his care on the day she died. During the sentencing, District Attorney Antonia Edwards said Fisher used Clorox wipes to try to conceal his crimes, scrubbing the child's face so hard he rubbed off the pigment. He used these Clorox wipes throughout her body, even placing them inside of her body. He was sentenced to 20 years in prison after taking a plea deal which was only offered to him so the family would not have to sit through a trial and learn the horrible details of his crime. Fortunately, he was recently found dead whilst in prison. The prison refused to reveal the cause of death which is expected to be revealed by the medical examiners. video_description: After i Paid off My House, My Drother's Wife Said.We're Going To Live Here, it's Family PropertyAnd Tried To Move in With Two kids. My FamilyAgreed. So i Said A Few Words That Made Her Cry.#reddit #ask #story  #friends #awkwardtuesdayphonecall #seconddateupdate #radioshow  #louquitsonair #quit #badboss 1080P
voice_to_text: My boyfriend claimed his ex was a psycho stalker, harassing him daily. When I discovered why she kept calling, I made one decision that burned his life to the ground. I didn't notice it at first. You think a woman would immediately recognize when her boyfriend of two years is lying about his psycho stalker ex. But Hayden was smart about it. He'd show me threatening texts from his crazy ex, delete her number in front of me, then restore everything when I left for work. It wasn't until she contacted my work email directly that I saw the first crack in his story. This woman is insane, Hayden said, reading her message over my shoulder. How did she even find where you work? The message didn't sound crazy. Please, just five minutes. He's lying to you. I have proof. Delete it, he said, not meeting my eyes. Has she been stalking you this whole time? I asked. Since we broke up two years ago, Sylvia. He pulled me close. I sat there stunned. We've been together for two years. Why is she still contacting you? Some people can't handle rejection, he said dismissively. I've tried everything. Police won't help without physical threats. I just protect you from most of it. I believed him until I met his ex. Three weeks later, I was at my usual coffee shop when a woman approached my table. Professional blazer, designer bag, and visibly pregnant. You're Sylvia, she said quietly. I studied her Face, pretty, put together. Nothing like the unstable person Hayden described. You're the ex. I'm not his ex. She placed her hand on her belly. I'm his girlfriend of four years. And this is his baby. The coffee shop seemed to tilt and stayed at my place five nights a week. We had dinner with my parents every Sunday. We were planning a vacation to Spain. What did she mean, girlfriend of four years? She pulled out her phone, hand steady, this is shocking. She showed me recent photos from last week. Hayden kissing her belly, their shared apartment lease from three months ago, an ultrasound dated two weeks prior with Hayden signature on the sign in sheet. Text messages where Hayden called me. This crazy girl from work who keeps hitting on me, and the stalker who won't leave me alone. Your work trips? I managed to ask. Those are his nights home with me. She scrolled through her calendar. He tells me he's at sales conferences. I took photos of every piece of evidence. We sat there for 90 minutes, comparing schedules, matching lies. Her name was Raya. They've been together since college. The pregnancy was planned. They were house shopping. She hadn't even known about me until recently. That night, when Hayden arrived at my apartment, I played my role perfectly. I kissed him hello, made dinner, asked about his day. He sprawled on my couch discussing our weekend plans while simultaneously texting that he Was stuck at a client dinner that was running late for three days. I investigated everything. Found his parents on Facebook, devoted Catholics who posted daily Bible verses. Discovered they paid his rent believing he was in graduate school for his NBA. Found out his father had gotten him the job at their friends investment firm. Learned they had no idea about Raya, the pregnancy, or me. Raya and I were now allies, sharing information.

video_description: After finding my girifriend's phone unlocked, idiscovered she and her friends had a group chatrating their boyfriends-i was dead last in everycategoryu, and they shared intimate photos mockingmy body, When i confronted her, she just laughedand said, "You should be grateful leven touchyou."#reddit #ask #story  #friends #awkwardtuesdayphonecall #seconddateupdate #radioshow  #louquitsonair #quit #badboss 1080P
voice_to_text: I wrote my little girl's name on every single school supplies. Okay, so I'm a 31 year old single mom to my daughter Emma, who's 8. Last month, I found out about this summer program at her school where kids can go before the year starts to do fun activities and get used to their new classroom. Emma was super excited about it, so we went shopping for all the required supplies. Now, here's the thing. At Emma's old school, kids would steal her stuff constantly. Her cute erasers would disappear, her good coloured pencils would vanish, and she'd come home upset, asking why everyone took her things. So this time, I wasn't taking any chances. I went full mom mode on those supplies. I used permanent marker to write E M M A. In big letters on every single crayon, marker, glue stick, and even the individual pieces of paper in her notebook. I glued her name onto her clear backpack with industrial adhesive so nobody could peel it off. I wrote her initials on every single page of her sketchbook. I even carved her name into her pencil case with a knife. Emma thought it was fun watching me label everything. We made it into a game where she'd hand me each item and I'd find a new spot to put her name. By the end, you couldn't look at any of her supplies without seeing E M M A. Written somewhere. First day of the program arrives, And Emma's bouncing off the walls, excited. I packed her labeled backpack, gave her a kiss, and sent her off. When I picked her up that afternoon, she looked confused and kind of sad. Turns out the teacher had made an announcement that all the supplies were going into a big communal pile to be shared equally among all the kids. Teacher said some families couldn't afford to buy supplies, so they were redistributing everything to make it fair. But here's where it gets crazy. When the teacher started sorting through the supplies and saw E M M A. Written on literally everything, she got annoyed. She apparently held up Emma's crayon box in front of the whole class and said, this is what happens when parents don't read the instructions properly and made Emma feel embarrassed. The teacher called me that evening. She explained that they pull all supplies together because not every family can afford the full list. Some kids show up with nothing, and they don't want anyone to feel left out. I told her I understood the concept, but asked why Emma had to be humiliated in front of everyone. The teacher said Emma would need to bring unmarked supplies if she wanted to continue the program. So I had a choice. Buy all new supplies and waste the money I'd already spent, or pull Emma out of something she was excited about. I decided to get creative instead. The next morning, I showed up at School with a bottle of nail polish remover and spent two hours in the parking lot scrubbing Emma's name off every single item. Other parents walking by kept staring at me like I was insane. Sitting there with a pile of school supplies trying to erase permanent marker. Some items were easy to fix, but others were ruined.
NA

Mental asylum workers. Who's the most memorable patient you've ever worked with? His name was Gregory, and he only spoke once a day. Right after breakfast, he'd sit in the rec room, sip his orange juice and say one sentence that made everyone's skin crawl, someone's going to die today. At first, all of us ignored him. Gregory had been in and out of mental hospitals his whole adult life. Schizophrenia, they said, delusions, nothing new for us workers. But then nurse Janet collapsed in the parking lot that same afternoon, massive heart attack, dead before the ambulance arrived. We figured it was just a coincidence. People die all the time, right? But the next week, Gregory did it again. Same routine, orange juice, same chair, same creepy voice. Someone's going to die today. That night, our night cook, Eddie, never made it home. His car wrapped around a tree on Highway 9. Police said he fell asleep at the wheel. That's when we started paying attention. I mean, really paying attention. We began writing down everything Gregory said and checking obituaries, hospital records, anything we could find. Six straight months, Gregory was right every single time. Sometimes it was a patient who had a stroke in their sleep. Sometimes it was a staff member's spouse whose cancer suddenly got worse. Sometimes it was random people we'd never heard of, but their names would show up in the paper the next day. We called in specialists from the university, psychiatrists Neurologists, even some professor who studied paranormal psychology, nobody could explain it. Gregory couldn't explain it either. When doctors asked him how he knew, he just shrug and say he didn't want to know. He just did. The whole staff was on edge. Every morning after breakfast, we'd all gather around and wait for Gregory's daily prediction like it was the weather report from hell. Some nurses started calling in sick just to avoid hearing it. But then one Tuesday morning, Gregory said something different. Something that made my blood freeze. This place will burn. Holy shit. We took that seriously. Fire drills every day. The maintenance team checked every single outlet, every space heater, every piece of kitchen equipment. Twice the fire department came through and gave us a clean inspection. Nothing was wrong. Everything looked perfect. Two weeks later, we had a new patient. Seventeen year old Caleb who tried to burn down his family's garage. During intake. Security missed the tiny lighter he'd hidden under his tongue. Rookie mistake. It was 3 a. M. When the smoke started. Caleb had lit a mop in the supply closet and the whole thing went up fast.

What's the single worst day you've ever had? I was working double shifts as a dishwasher at this hotel downtown. The pay wasn't great, but I needed every dollar I could get for my daughter's braces. She's 12 and super self conscious about her crooked teeth. I've been saving up in this old coffee jar for months, putting away whatever I could spare after rent and groceries. My boss, Greg, was honestly the worst. This guy would lose his mind over anything. Leave a single spot on a plate. He'd scream at you in front of everyone. Come back from break two minutes late, he threatened to write you up. Everyone who worked there hated him. But we all needed the job. That Tuesday started off bad. There was this massive car accident on the highway that had traffic backed up for miles. I'm sitting there watching the clock, knowing Greg's gonna flip when I walk in late, 20 minutes past my shift start. I finally make it to the kitchen. Greg's face was already red before I even got my apron on. You're late, Raymond! He screamed loud enough for the whole kitchen to hear. This is strike two for you, buddy. One more screw up and you're gone. I tried explaining about the crash, even showed him the traffic report on my phone, but he just waved me off and said he'd already written me up. The other dishwashers gave me these sympathetic looks, but nobody said anything. We all knew better than to get on Greg's bad side. Morning was already rough, but then around noon, everything went completely sideways. This guest came down to the front desk claiming her engagement ring was missing from the bathroom upstairs. It was this huge diamond ring worth, like, $15,000. Hotel security pulled up all the footage from that floor. Turns out I was the only staff member who'd been in that bathroom around the time she said it went missing. I'd gone in there to clean and restock the towels like I always do. The cameras didn't show anything clear, but because I was the only one logged into that wing, they immediately blamed me. Next thing I know, the police are there asking me questions. Greg demanded I empty my pockets right there in front of everyone. The other dishwashers, the cooks, even some guests were watching. I turned my pockets inside out, took off my shoes, everything. I had nothing on me except my wallet and keys. But it didn't matter. Greg said they had to suspend me pending investigation. Twenty minutes later, I'm walking out of there with no job and no idea when I'd be able to work again. Bus ride home was the longest 40 minutes of my life. I kept thinking about my daughter asking when she could get her braces. And I had no idea what I was going to tell her. When I got to my apartment building, something felt wrong. My front door was wide open. First I thought maybe I just forgotten to lock it. But then I saw the mess inside. My TV was gone. My laptop that I'd saved up for two years to buy was gone. My daughter's PlayStation that she got for Christmas was gone. But the worst part was when I went

At Thanksgiving dinner, my sister stood up and announced, we voted, and you're not family anymore. Everyone cheered. I laughed softly and said, then I guess you won't need this. I placed a folder on the table. The moment she opened it, she started screaming. Before we carve the Turkey, Natalie said, rising with that rehearsed smile, there's something we need to say. The room went silent. We had a family vote. You're not family anymore! Cheering. Actual cheering. My cousin Laura clapped like she was at a concert. Uncle Ben raised his wine glass. Even my mother laughed and said, well, someone had to say it. My dad just sipped his beer and muttered, it's probably for the best. Wow, I said, pushing back slowly. You rehearse this? Natalie grinned wider. You've been toxic for years. We're done pretending. It's unanimous, my mother added. I looked around. No one spoke up. Good, I said quietly, reaching into my bag. I figured this might happen. I pulled out a thick folder and placed it in the center. The heavy thought of it hitting the table cut through the laughter. Natalie blinked. What is that? I smiled and folded my arms. Why don't you find out? She snatched it and ripped it open, that snide smirk forming. Then she turned the first page and stopped smiling. Her face went pale. Then she screamed. Blood curdling horror movie scream. Her chair crashed behind her as she bolted upright, slamming the folder shut. You monster! She cried. You messed up freak! Joel! Her husband grabbed the folder. His jaw dropped. Is this. I nodded once. It's all real. Every word, every receipt, every screenshot. Dead silence. You were so sure I wouldn't fight back, I said, standing slowly, so sure I'd stay the quiet one. The doormat. The cash cow. Let me tell you what was in that folder. Five years of records. Over $78,000 sent to family members, all documented. $8,000 for Joel's rehab. Actually a spa retreat. $2,300 for Natalie's emergency dental work, elective veneers. $12,000 for mom's credit card debt. $4,500 for a family emergency. Actually a Cabo trip. Screw. Screenshots of Natalie calling me a cash cow with no spine, posts where they mocked me, texts where she called me manipulative for refusing to co sign her business loan. And the cherry on top, hotel receipts showing Natalie spent three nights in Santa Monica with someone named Alyssa, charged to Joel's credit card. That's what made her scream. She wasn't just exposed, she. It was dismantled, fact by fact. Joel flipped through pages, his face paling. What's this about Santa Monica? Who's Alyssa? Why were you at a hotel for three nights on my credit card? Silence. Let's be reasonable. My mom tried. Sure, I said. Let's talk about when you called me a parasite while cashing my check. We were under stress, she stammered. No, I snapped. You were under stress, and I bailed you out every time. The one time I say no, I'm the enemy. My dad spoke up. You're making this bigger than it is. You let them do this for years. I said, you knew. You saw it. You let it happen because it was easier. You're just bitter because no one needs you anymore. Natalie shouted. Wrong. I said coldly, I'm not bitter. I'm done. You think this

Foster children, what's the most insane thing you ever experienced? When I was 10, I got placed with the lanes. They seemed normal at first, nice house, good food, even gave me my own bedroom with cartoon wallpaper. But something felt weird from day one. They never let me go outside alone, not even to the mailbox. If I wanted to play in the backyard, one of them had to watch me through the window. When I asked why, they said it was for my safety. I figured all foster parents were protective like that. At school, if I got any papers or notes, I had to hand them over the second I walked in the door. They said they needed to check everything. For my own good, they locked up my backpack at night and went through it while I slept. I thought this was normal, too. The weirdest thing was the computer. I had one in the living room, but I wasn't allowed to touch it ever. They said the internet was dangerous for kids. When other kids at school talked about games or videos they saw online, I just nodded along and pretended I knew what they meant. One night I lost a tooth. I put it under my pillow like always, expecting to wake up to $1 or some quarters. Instead, I found a tiny folded note written in handwriting I'd never seen before. It said, you're not who they think you are. Check behind the Mirror. I scared out of my mind. At school the next day, I asked my teacher, Missus Kim, if the Tooth Fairy ever left notes instead of money. She laughed and said no, the Tooth Fairy only brings coins. That made me even more confused. At night, while the lanes were downstairs watching their usual cop shows, I carefully pulled the mirror off my bedroom wall. My hands were shaking the whole time. Behind it was a small hole cut into the wall and inside was a plastic bag stuffed with papers. I pulled everything out. Birth certificates, newspaper clippings, photos of kids who looked like me but weren't me. One photo showed a little girl with my exact eyes but different hair. Another showed a teenager who could have been my sister. Then I found the missing child flyer. It had a picture of a six year old girl named Sophie Blanchard, missing for four years. The girl in the photo looked exactly like me, just younger. My stomach dropped to the floor. There were handwritten notes too. They rename all the kids. Tell someone the truth. Call Aunt Jane. She's still looking. I spent the next week acting totally normal, eating dinner and doing homework like nothing happened. But inside I was freaking out. During lunch at school, I snuck into the classroom and use the phone to call the number written on one of the papers. A woman answered and when I said the name Sophie Blanchard She started crying so hard I could barely understand her. She kept asking where I was, if I was safe, if I remembered her. I hung up because I got scared. That weekend, two people from child services showed up at our door without warning.

How did the worst misunderstanding of your life lead to meeting your spouse? The building manager knocked on my door at 6 a m. Sir, open up or we'll call the police. My neighbour hid behind him, carefully holding a binder labelled evidence. The manager cleared his throat. Sir, we need to discuss some serious allegations. We've received complaints of your stalking behaviour. Would you mind letting us in? I was surprised. Stalking? No, I'm sure this is all just a funny misunderstanding, I said. Thank. What could I have even done that felt like stalking? Then let us in, he insisted coldly. They walked in and immediately started looking around. My neighbor pointed at my balcony. That's where he watches me every morning. Look, there's even a notebook. She grabbed it before I could react and started reading out loud. 5:00am, she left, crying. 602:00am, she came back. 7:00am, she looked tired, didn't eat breakfast. Her hands started shaking in fear. The manager frowned. You're documenting her routine? I shook my head. No. Well, yes, but it's because this goes back three months. Every single day? She asked, covering her mouth. My neighbor spotted my phone on the counter. Stay right where you are. Passcode now, he said, radioing security in case things went south. 2,352, I told. They opened up my gallery and scrolled through the dozens of pictures from the park. She was in every single one. Oh my god, she said, showing the manager. He's been Photographing me everywhere I go. The manager's expression darkened. Okay, I know this looks bad, but please let me explain. I begged, but my neighbor refused, pulling out more evidence. Text messages from her friends. Look, he followed me to the pet store last week. My friend saw him hiding behind the dog food aisle. The manager studied the photos. He always asked me weird questions, too. He's like, are you going anywhere overnight this weekend? And stuff. Like, why would you need to know that? My neighbor was almost crying, and he somehow knew my mom was sick. I never told him that, either. The manager noticed a she's bag by the door. What's in there? Wait. He opened it. Out came five different types of cat food with heating pads and antibiotics. They stared at it completely confused. I side, I've been trying to tell you guys I'm not stalking. Look. I grabbed my phone and opened up the gallery again, zooming into the pictures. Each one had pictures of the stray cats my neighbor started taking care of a few months ago. The manager and my neighbor exchanged looks like I just made up the worst excuse ever. Right, cats, the manager said sarcastically. You expect us to believe you've been stalking her for cats? My neighbor shook her head. That's sick. Using innocent animals as your cover story. No, I just. Look, I said, frustrated, grabbing my note.

What's the most shocking thing you've accidentally discovered? I finally successfully snuck my crush over one night without my parents noticing. But as he had to go home, we were almost in the clear. We snuck downstairs. But as soon as we opened the front door, the lights flicked on. I felt my heart stop and saw my dad standing there in his boxers. What the hell is this? He was holding my iPad, scrolling through our texts from earlier where he asked if he could come over after my parents went to bed. My dad charged at him and this poor guy scrambled out the front door while my dad shouting about get out and never come back. Dad's face is purple as he announces, I'm installing cameras, every room, every angle. You wanna act like you can't be trusted? Fine. Now you can't be. Mom stumbles downstairs asking what's happening, but Dad's already on his phone ordering equipment from some security website. I thought he was joking, but by noon, they were literally everywhere, living room, kitchen, hallway, even one pointed at my bedroom door. 47 cameras total, I counted. He sets up this whole command center on his laptop in his room, multiple screens showing every angle of our house like he's running a casino. This is for your safety. There won't be any teen pregnancy in my house. Day three and I can't breathe without dad texting me. I'm doing homework and who was at the Door, it's the mailman. He rushed home one day because he heard me talking on the phone while my friend Reese was coming over to study. He burst into my room thinking Reese was a boy literally holding a baseball bat. However, I started noting weird things going on. I decided to check his camera system myself one day and noticed activity. At 3:00am, Dad emerges from his room fully dressed, jeans, boots, like he's ready to go on a date. Mom's already completely passed out from her long day and doesn't even notice him leaving. He checks the cameras to make sure I'm in bed, not knowing I'm watching him check on me. Then he just leaves. Nothing happens until he comes back at 4:00am, hair messy, sneaks back into bed with mom before she noticed he was even gone. I didn't believe what I was seeing. I had to make sure this was real. But the very next night, one night, the camera catches him coming back with lipstick on his collar that he frantically scrubs off in the downstairs bathroom. I started crying while watching this. My, my own dad even going as far as to say, if I catch that kid around here again, I'll kill him. My mom just laughs. I can't stand watching her live this lie anymore. Saturday night, after dad sneaks out again, I wake mom. There's something you need to see. I show her all the footage, him leaving at 2:00am Coming back to shoveled the lipstick, everything. Mom's face goes from confusion to rage. Oh, my god. After 20 years.

My parents sent a group message. We're giving your trust fund to your sister. She has kids. You don't. I stared at my phone for 10 minutes straight. My sister Amber had three kids under 5 and was always posting about being broke on Facebook. I had been saving my trust fund for a house down payment. I've been working at target for two years while going to nursing school just so I wouldn't have to touch it early. Group chat kept buzzing. Amber was sending crying, laughing emojis and saying, thank you so much, mom and dad. This changes everything. My parents were explaining how family comes first and kids need stability. Nobody was responding to my messages asking if this was a joke. I called mom directly. She picked up on the first ring like she was expecting it. Honey, we know you're upset, but Amber really needs this right now. You're young and single. You have time to build your own savings. I'm 26 and in nursing school. I said that money was supposed to help me buy a house. Well, maybe if you focused on finding a nice man instead of working all the time, you'd understand what real responsibility looks like. I hung up and drove straight to their house. Dad was mowing the lawn like nothing happened. When he saw me get out of my car, he turned off the mower and walked over. Before you say anything, this decision is final, he said. Amber has three mouths to feed. And what about my mouth? What about my future? You're selfish if you can't see why this makes sense. That night I called my grandma Helen, my mom's mom. She was the one who actually set up the trust funds in the first place when I was little. She listened to the whole story without interrupting those idiots. She said, finally, they can't just give away your trust fund. I specifically set it up so only you can access it. When you turn 25, your parents don't have legal control over it anymore. My heart stopped. What do you mean? I mean, call the bank tomorrow and ask for your account information. That money is yours, not theirs to give away. The next morning, I called First National Bank. After being transferred three times, I finally got to the trust department. The lady pulled up my account and confirmed everything. The trust fund had automatically transferred to my name six months ago on my 25th birthday. My parents had zero access to it. Actually, she said. someone tried to make unauthorized changes to this account yesterday. We flagged it as suspicious activity. I almost laughed out loud. My parents had tried to steal my money and failed. But here's where it gets good. I didn't tell them right away. Instead, I let them think their plan worked. I watched Amber post about her shopping spree, buying new furniture and clothes for the kids. I watched my parents pat themselves on the back for being such generous grandparents. Two weeks later, Amber called me crying. The bank says there was an error. They can't find the money transfer. Mom and dad are freaking out because they already told me I could have it. That's weird, I said. Try not to smile. The family group chat exploded. My parents were demanding answers from the bank. Amber was having a meltdown about returning all the stuff she bought on credit, thinking the money was coming. Dad was threatening to sue the bank for losing the transfer. Finally, I sent one message to the group chat. Hey, guys, talk to the bank today. Turns out the trust fund money has been in my personal account since my birthday. Grandma Helen set it up that way on purpose. Thanks for trying to steal from me, though. Really showed me where I stand in this family. Mom called me screaming, you knew this whole time and let us look like idiots. You looked like thieves, actually, because that's what you tried to be. You're being cruel to your sister. She has children and I have student loans. But I guess that doesn't matter because I don't have kids yet. The best part was when Amber had to return everything she bought, she posted a long Facebook rant about how banks can't be trusted and how the system is broken. She never mentioned that she tried to spend money that Was never actually hers. My parents didn't talk to me for 3 months. When they finally reached out, it was because they needed me to co sign for Amber's car loan since her credit was destroyed from all the returned purchases. I sent back one word, no.

Australia has a lot of spiders, but recently we found a new one cause of course we fuckin did. And the new one is the most certified Australia moment I've ever seen. For a bit of context, one of the several thousand spider species we are home to is the Sydney funnel web, the deadliest spider on the planet. Cause of course it's down here. Where the fuck else did you think you were gonna find it? These scary looking fuckers are highly venomous and can flatline you with a bite in 15 minutes. And if you think wearing thick clothes will save you, be aware the bastards have fangs long enough to punch through shoe leather. Now why do I bring these little nightmares up? What is the one thing worse than a spider rocking armour piercing rounds that can send you to heaven with same day delivery? A bigger spider rocking the same perk setup. That's right. Australian scientists have found a brand new species of this funnel web that is even bigger. How much bigger? Well the standard Sydney funnel web grows to around 5 cm or 2 inches and I mean if you're asking me two inches is more than enough, two inches is actually fucking huge by comparison. This is the new one. It's twice the fucking size cunt, 4 inches of eight legged menace.

My sister sent me a wedding gift list asking for a car, an apartment and designer bags. When I told her I wasn't buying any of it, she exploded and screamed, then don't even come. So I didn't. What happened next had the entire family blaming her. The PDF was titled Wedding Gift List mandatory. I thought it was a joke until I scrolled through 12 pages of demands. My twenty six year old sister Mia wanted a white Audi Q5. Forty five thousand dollars, a thirty thousand dollar down payment for a Manhattan apartment and three Hermes bags totaling 15 thousand dollars. Each item marked priority in bold red letters with delivery deadlines. I worked two jobs through college, paid my own loans, finally built some savings after years of ramen dinners. Meanwhile, Mia lived with our parents rent free, switching jobs every six months, posting vacation photos from trips they funded. I texted back, I'm not buying you a car or apartment. I'll get something reasonable off a normal registry. Her response came within 30 seconds. Wow, are you serious? You're my brother. This is what family does for each other. If you won't step up when I need you most, don't bother coming to the wedding. That hit different. Not disappointment, relief mixed with anger. Relief because I'd always walked on eggshells with the golden child who got a brand new BMW at 18 while I drove a rusted Honda with 200,000 miles. Anger because she was Weaponizing her wedding day to manipulate me into financial slavery. My parents called within two hours. Lucas, me has been crying all afternoon, mom said, voice tight with that familiar guilt trip tone. She says, you told her you won't contribute to wedding gifts. What's gotten into you? She didn't ask me to contribute. She demanded I buy her a car and apartment with a shopping list longer than most people's mortgage applications. Dad cut in with his authoritative voice. Lucas, if you can't support your sister on her special day, maybe you should sit this one out. We don't need your negativity ruining the Celebration for everyone else. The betrayal stunk fine. I won't come for a week. Complete silence. Then my cousin Jake called. Dude, Mia lost it. At her bridal shower, she threw a 200 dollar Kate Spade bag back at Aunt Linda for not getting the 3,000 dollar tote bag of Veneta she requested. Said, if you can't follow simple instructions, don't bother showing up. Half the room walked out. Finally, Mia was showing everyone who she really was. Mom texted, we need to talk. At their house that evening, dad had a new stack of papers waiting. A revised list of reasonable compromises. Catered rehearsal dinner, $8,000. Photographer travel costs, $2,500. Honeymoon suite contribution, $3,000. So Mia told me not to come. You supported her and now you want money anyway. It's about family, mom said. People will notice if you're not there. Good. Let Them talk. Mia slammed the table. You've made me look like a fool. I didn't make you look like anything. You did that yourself. A week before the wedding, a rushed invitation arrived. Just Lucas, you're invited back. Please come. Mia. No apology, no acknowledgement. My cousin called again. She's panicking. Half the wedding party is dropping out. Your aunts won't speak.

video_description: BREAKING NEWS ABOUT THE BLACKHAWK HELICOPTER THAT FLEW INTO THE AMERICAN AIRLINES PLANE HEADED FROM
voice_to_text: Guys, this is major breaking news about the Blackhawk helicopter that flew into the airplane in d. C. In January. The female pilot in this crash was reportedly given several warnings to turn but she did not. New details have emerged about Rebecca Loback, who was the female co pilot of this Blackhawk helicopter. Her male co pilot told her to turn away multiple time, meaning that they identified the American Airlines flight carrying those 64 people. Also meaning that she ignored his request and orders to turn. On Sunday, the New York Times released new detail stating that that co pilot directly told her to turn away. They said not only was the Black Hawk flying too high, but in the final seconds before the crash, its pilot failed to heed a directive from her co pilot and Army, Army instructor to change the course. The Blackhawk was 15 seconds away from crossing paths with the jet. He told her he believed that air traffic control wanted them to turn left towards East River Bank. If they would have turned left, it would have opened up more space between the helicopter and this American Airlines flight. She didn't turn left though. Now, as you guys know, it took quite a while before they would release Rebecca Lobo's name, 3 days to be exact. And sources are claiming it's because they wanted to scrub her social media. So why did they wanna scrub it? Why did she not turn left? We Need more. What happened here and why?

video_description: SC PREACHER‚ÄôS SON HOLD 4 ADULTS CAPTIVE IN BASEMENT FOR YRS! Donnie Birchfield is from Lancaster SC
voice_to_text: A pastor's son kept four adults captive for years in his basement. This is 35 year old Donnie Ray Birchfield of Lancaster, South Carolina. It was recently found that he was keeping four adults captive in his basement, but only because it was finally reported that one of those adults had passed. Now as I've said, a 9 1 1 call was made and it was the day after this woman had died. And so police arrived and they found these other three adults in a basement seemingly controlled by Donnie. They wouldn't leave the basement under his instruction until they came back with a warrant and he had no choice. It was also found that he would deny food, he would deny water. Again, they were not allowed to leave for years from this basement area. They were physically and emotionally abused. Two of these captives were a husband and a wife. The wife is the one who passed. The other two that were being held captive were two women that were both allegedly in a romantic relationship with Donnie. One of them since September of 24 and the other had been with him since 2015. As I said, Donnie is a preacher son from a church in the area. At this time he has been arrested. He has about 16 charges and also financial crime charges because he allegedly used credit cards and took money out of bank accounts and of course as a charges for false imprisonment. Donnie Is being held without bond, but make sure to follow me because I'm gonna keep you guys updated on this one.

This woman never opens the door with her hands, because if she touches anything, she has to wash her hands immediately. And every time she does, she has to squeeze two squirts of hand sanitizer evenly. And she has to wash her hands for more than 10 minutes. Even if she turns off the tap after washing her hands, the woman will feel that her hands are dirty again, so she washes them again. She even takes a hair dryer with her every time she goes out, because if someone touches her hair, she'll go to the bathroom. She takes out her shampoo and conditioner and washes her hair all over again. The woman chose to see a doctor because of her obsessive compulsive disorder. But what she didn't expect was that all the patients were OCD patients. The man in front of her never stepped on the lines of the grid, and when his glasses fall off, he has to hold them with both hands. The man suffers from severe symmetry OCD. Everything must be neatly arranged. But the funniest of all is this man, because he has the most beatable form of OCD. Every five minutes he would provoke others without any limits. The more nervous he is, the more he provokes. In the last half an hour, he made 56 provocations. But he didn't calculate this figure himself, it was calculated by a taxi driver. He suffers from compulsive counting. He locked a passenger in his car Just to count the railings. And this lady has the most common checking compulsion. Every time she leaves the house, she feels that the window is not closed. In order to deepen her impression, she would do a silky smooth move after locking the door. She even feels like she doesn't have her house keys when she gets into the lift. If she doesn't go home to check, she'll feel like she's lost her soul for the rest of the day. At that moment, the assistant pushed in and said that the doctor's flight was late. This definitely stirred up a hornet's nest. The group's obsessive compulsive disorder got worse. However, there was another girl who sat quietly and didn't say a word. She doesn't look like she has OCD. The next moment was unexpected.
